discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
ifconfig ecth0 promisc enables promiscuous mode which allows a network device to intercept and read each network packet that arrives in its entirety. Since the question states "Network Monitoring" this would be the best & only answer

comments.content: What module/section can I find that in?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Question has a spelling error which threw me off for a while. the correct answer is A but should say "ifconfig eth0 promisc"

Selected Answer: A
This is a BS question zero study material for Net+ says you need to memorize the the Ifconfig extras. Its just IPConfig stuff

Selected Answer: A
Inorder to mirror a port you would have to use a port command. So the command would have to have the inter in the answer.

Selected Answer: A
The 'ifconfig eth0 promisc' cmd would enable promiscuous mode on eth0 so the interface can capture and process network traffic coming to it. The switch's mirror port is duplicating traffic on another port on the switch and sending the mirrored traffic through its mirror port which is connected to the linux computer on eth1.

I'm still trying to understand if promiscuous mode should be set on eth1 instead of eth0 since eth1 is the interface where the mirrored traffic is being sent to be captured and analyzed... The Linux computer's main duty is for network monitoring anyway so I guess setting it to eth0 is probably for general network monitoring/control?

Eitherway, it's the only answer that makes sense given the other choices but if someone can clarify that it would be appreciated.

comments.content: Yeah, the issue with this question is, that it would have to be the interface of the mirror port that had to be set to promiscuous mode, not the one of the monitoring machine. If there is no mistake made in creating the question, it would only leave us with eth1 up as a sensible solution.

discussion.content: no idea

questions.question_text: A network requirement calls for the network traffic of a specific department within a campus network to be monitored. The network has users from each department located in multiple buildings. Which of the following should be configured to meet this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I am leaning towards B and D. The flow control, appears to have a little do to with the question. Anyone?

Selected Answer: BD
802.1Q is a standard for VLAN tagging, which allows the network administrator to segment the network traffic of different departments into separate VLANs. This makes it easier to monitor and manage the traffic of each department.

Port mirroring is a feature that allows the network administrator to copy the traffic from one or more ports to another port for analysis. By configuring port mirroring on the ports connected to the specific department, the network administrator can monitor the traffic of that department in real-time.

D. Port mirroring: Port mirroring (also known as SPAN - Switched Port Analyzer) is a feature that allows the traffic on one port (or a set of ports) to be mirrored and sent to another port for monitoring purposes. This would enable the monitoring of the network traffic for a specific department.

B. 802.1Q: 802.1Q is a standard for VLAN tagging. By configuring VLANs, you can logically segment the network based on departments. This helps in organizing and monitoring network traffic on a departmental basis.

Selected Answer: BD
BD make the most sense.

Selected Answer: BD
B & D.

Selected Answer: BD
B & D are the correct answer

Selected Answer: BD
The correct options are: B & D

Selected Answer: BD
Yes. B and D

questions.question_text: A wireless technician is working to upgrade the wireless infrastructure for a company. The company currently uses the 802.11g wireless standard on all access points. The company requires backward compatibility and is requesting the least expensive solution. Which of the following should the technician recommend to the company?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. 802.11n

Selected Answer: D
D. 802.11n

Selected Answer: D
Per ChatGPT 

D. 802.11n

802.11n is designed to be backward compatible with the 802.11g standard, allowing devices using the older standard to communicate with devices using the newer standard. Additionally, 802.11n offers improved data rates, better coverage, and overall enhanced performance compared to 802.11g, making it a practical and cost-effective upgrade option.

Options A, B, and C (802.11a, 802.11ac, and 802.11ax) are newer standards that may offer improved performance and features, but they may also be more expensive and not entirely necessary for the company's current requirements, especially considering the need for backward compatibility and cost-effectiveness.

A sign won't help. Entry log on itself won't help either, in this case it wouldn't prevent any second person walking in behind and it would only have the entry of the employee who walked in first. Camera records but does not prevent. Awareness training is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: B
Awareness training educates them about the importance of following security protocols, including not allowing others to tailgate when entering a secure facility. This ensures that employees understand the potential security risks associated with their actions and are therefore less likely to repeat them. Remember, the human factor is often the weakest link in security, so training is crucial.

Selected Answer: B
B Awareness training

Selected Answer: B
The staff require training. If they had it, they would not let someone walk in.

hard to choose here but i would go with C. Entry log

questions.question_text: An employee walked into a secure facility and allowed a newly hired employee to walk in as well. Which of the following is the BEST solution to prevent this from happening again?

choices.B: Change the IPv4 address on Host 2 to 192.168.0.112.
choices.D: Update the DNS server on Host 1 to 192.168.0.53.
choices.A: Change the default gateway on Host 1 to 192.168.1.1.
choices.C: Reconfigure the subnet masks on both hosts.

discussion.content:
Correction was not included with my post:
Forgot to type the beginning of the range.
Valid Usable Device IPs: 192.168.0.1 - 192.168.1.254

Nothing wrong with the question.
Valid IP range with 255.255.254.0 "/23" subnet mask
Subnet IP: 192.168.0.0
Valid Usable Device IPs: 192.168.1.254
Broadcast IP: 192.168.1.255
Since Host1, Host2, Default Gateway, DNS servers all have configured an IP that is in the above valid range, Answers A,B,C are unnecessary.
Host1 can communicate. Host2 cannot. Troubleshooting 101, don't overlook the easy and obvious. Host1 and Host2 are statically configured and someone "fat-fingered" Gateway IP on Host1. 
People in the discussion mentioned that Host1 would still be able to query a DNS server at 192.168.1.53, which is true. Your DNS server does not have to be on the same IP subnet as a device anyway. In this network there is only 1 DNS server, and its IP is 192.168.0.53.
Probably the creator of this dump badly formulated the question that was on the exam

Selected Answer: D
D. Update the DNS server on Host 1 to 192.168.0.53.

Selected Answer: D
D makes the most sense. Host 1 is the issue, so making changes to host 2 doesn't make any sense since other users can connect to it just fine
Clueing into hostname indicates a DNS issue and changing it to match the DNS on host 2 should fix it

comments.content: It's because it is unable to reach by the hostname, and DNS is what converts IP to hostnames. D is correct here, I hope this helps.

This question is rediculous, I agree with you that it should be able to reach the dns on 1.53 because they are both on the same subnet, according to the subnet mask. None of these answers are correct. The only thing I can see is that they want you to know that dns converts the hostname to ip, and want you to think about dns. Its the LEAST wrong answer. still stupid.
It's a called a "red herring" .. mean misleading questions. Almost seems like Comptia wants customers to fail the exam to pay another 350 bucks to retake it.

discussion.content: It can still reach 192.168.1.53 since they are on the same network.. I am unsure why the answer is D
